====[[Ski jumping]]==== *[[2009–10 Ski Jumping World Cup|World Cup]] in [[Schattenbergschanze|Oberstdorf]], Germany: **HS 213 (Ski flying):
====[[Snooker]]==== *[[2010 Welsh Open (snooker)|Welsh Open]] in [[Newport Centre|Newport]], [[Wales]]: **Final: [[John Higgins (snooker player)|John Higgins]] {{cc3|SCO}} (2) def. [[Ali Carter]] {{cc3|ENG}} (1) 9–4
====[[Tennis]]==== *[[2010 Australian Open|Australian Open]] in [[Melbourne & Olympic Parks|Melbourne]], Australia, day 14: **[[2010 Australian Open – Men's Singles#Finals|Men's Singles Final]]: ***'''[[Roger Federer]]''' {{cc3|SUI}} [1] def. [[Andy Murray]] {{cc3|GBR}} [5] 6–3, 6–4, 7–6(11) ****Federer wins his fourth Australian Open title and extends his record of Grand Slam titles to 16. **[[2010 Australian Open – Mixed Doubles#Finals|Mixed Doubles Final]]: ***'''[[Cara Black]]''' {{cc3|ZIM}}/'''[[Leander Paes]]''' {{cc3|IND}} [1] def. [[Ekaterina Makarova]] {{cc3|RUS}}/[[Jaroslav Levinský]] {{cc3|CZE}} 7–5, 6–3 ****Black and Paes win their second Grand Slam title together. Paes wins his 11th Grand Slam title and gets level with fellow Indian [[Mahesh Bhupathi]]. Black wins her ninth Grand Slam title and completes a career Grand Slam in mixed doubles.

====[[Bandy]]==== *[[Bandy World Championship|Men's World Championship]] in Moscow, Russia: **Group B 4th place game: {{Bandy|Mongolia}} 5–5 (1–2 [[Penalty shootout|pen.]]) {{Bandy|Hungary}} **Group B 2nd place game: {{Bandy|Latvia}} 7–4 {{Bandy|Netherlands}} **Qualification game: {{Bandy|USA}} 9–6 {{Bandy|Canada}} ***USA will remain in Group A and Canada in Group B. **Semifinals: ***{{Bandy|Sweden}} 9–4 {{Bandy|Finland}} ***{{Bandy|Russia}} 16–3 {{Bandy|Kazakhstan}}
====[[Cricket]]==== *[[2010 U-19 Cricket World Cup#Final|U-19 World Cup Final]] in [[Bert Sutcliffe Oval|Lincoln]], New Zealand: **{{cr|Australia}} 207/9 (50 overs); {{cr|Pakistan}} 182 (46.4 overs). '''Australia win by 25 runs'''. *[[2010 Associates Twenty20 Series in Kenya|Associates Twenty20 Series in Kenya]]: **{{cr|Uganda}} 123/9 (20/20 ov); {{cr|Kenya}} 127/2 (17.2/20 ov) in [[Gymkhana Club Ground|Nairobi]]. '''Kenya win by 8 wickets'''.

====[[American football]]==== *[[2009–10 NFL playoffs|NFL]] Conference Championships: **[[AFC Championship Game]]: (1) [[2009 Indianapolis Colts season|Indianapolis Colts]] 30, (5) [[2009 New York Jets season|New York Jets]] 17 *** The Jets take a 17–6 lead in the second quarter before [[Peyton Manning]] throws three touchdown passes against the league's number one defense. This will be the Colts' fourth trip to the Super Bowl, all in Miami. **[[NFC Championship Game]]: (1) [[2009 New Orleans Saints season|New Orleans Saints]] 31, (2) [[2009 Minnesota Vikings season|Minnesota Vikings]] 28 (OT) *** In the first NFC Championship game ever played at the [[Louisiana Superdome|Superdome]], [[Garrett Hartley]]'s 40-yard field goal in overtime sends the Saints to their first ever Super Bowl. The Vikings commit five turnovers.

====[[American football]]==== *[[2009–10 NFL playoffs|NFL]] Wild Card Weekend (seeds in parentheses): **[[American Football Conference|AFC]]: (6) [[Baltimore Ravens]] 33, (3) [[New England Patriots]] 14 ***The Patriots suffer their worst home playoff loss since {{nfly|1978}} as [[Ray Rice]] begins the game with an 88-yard touchdown run and the Ravens score 24 first quarter points. **[[National Football Conference|NFC]]: (4) [[Arizona Cardinals]] 51, (5) [[Green Bay Packers]] 45 ([[Overtime (sports)|OT]]) ***[[Karlos Dansby]] scores the Cardinals' winning touchdown on a 17-yard fumble return, after the Packers rally from a 21-point deficit to tie the score in regulation time. The game sets NFL playoff records for total points (96) and touchdowns (13). In a losing effort, [[Aaron Rodgers]] becomes the 12th quarterback in history to [[List of NFL quarterbacks who have passed for 400 or more yards in a game|pass for 400 yards]] in a postseason game.

====[[American football]]==== *[[2009 NFL season|NFL]] Week 17 – end of regular season (division champions in '''bold''', teams that earned a first-round bye in '''''bold italics''''', teams that earned wild card berths in ''italics''): **[[Buffalo Bills]] 30, '''''[[Indianapolis Colts]]''''' 7 ***The Colts lose their second straight game, but still end the season with a league-best 14–2 record. **[[Cleveland Browns]] 23, [[Jacksonville Jaguars]] 17 ***The Jags lose their fourth straight game and miss the playoffs. **'''''[[Minnesota Vikings]]''''' 44, [[New York Giants]] 7 ***The Vikings earn a first-round bye in the NFC playoffs. **[[Atlanta Falcons]] 20, [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] 10 **[[Houston Texans]] 34, '''[[New England Patriots]]''' 27 ***The Texans, who rally from 14 points down in the fourth quarter, are eliminated from the playoffs on a tiebreaker because the Ravens and Jets both win. **[[Carolina Panthers]] 23, '''''[[New Orleans Saints]]''''' 10 ***The Saints end the season with three straight losses after a 13–0 start. **[[Chicago Bears]] 37, [[Detroit Lions]] 23 **[[San Francisco 49ers]] 28, [[St. Louis Rams]] 6 ***The Rams suffer their eighth straight loss and end the season with a league-worst 1–15 record, that earn them the top selection at the [[2010 NFL Draft|Draft]]. They would also become the 9th team to finish a season at 1-15. **[[Pittsburgh Steelers]] 30, [[Miami Dolphins]] 24 ***The Steelers are eliminated from the playoff on a tiebreaker despite their win, thus the 2003–2004 New England Patriots remain the last repeat [[Super Bowl]] champions, while the Dolphins, the host team for [[Super Bowl XLIV]], are also eliminated from the postseason with their third straight loss. **''[[Green Bay Packers]]'' 33, '''[[Arizona Cardinals]]''' 7 ***The teams will meet again in the Wild Card Round [[University of Phoenix Stadium|at Arizona]] on January 10. **''[[Baltimore Ravens]]'' 21, [[Oakland Raiders]] 13 ***The Ravens claim an AFC wild card berth with this win, and will meet the New England Patriots in the Wild Card Round [[Gillette Stadium|at Foxboro]] on January 10. **'''[[Dallas Cowboys]]''' 24, ''[[Philadelphia Eagles]]'' 0 ***The Cowboys clinch the [[NFC East]] title, and earn [[Cowboys Stadium|home field advantage]] in a rematch against the Eagles in the Wild Card Round on January 9. **'''''[[San Diego Chargers]]''''' 23, [[Washington Redskins]] 20 ***The Chargers extend their winning streak to 11 games. **[[Tennessee Titans]] 17, [[Seattle Seahawks]] 13 ***[[Chris Johnson (running back)|Chris Johnson]] breaks [[Marshall Faulk]]'s record for total yards from scrimmage and becomes the sixth player to rush for 2,000 yards in a season. **[[Kansas City Chiefs]] 44, [[Denver Broncos]] 24 ***Despite the Broncos' [[Kyle Orton]] becoming the sixth quarterback this season to [[List of NFL quarterbacks who have passed for 400 or more yards in a game|pass for 400 yards in a game]], they are eliminated from the playoffs with this loss. **''[[NBC Sunday Night Football|Sunday Night Football]]'': ''[[New York Jets]]'' 37, '''[[Cincinnati Bengals]]''' 0 ***A crushing win in the last regular-season game at [[Giants Stadium]] gives the Jets an AFC wild card berth and a rematch with the Bengals [[Paul Brown Stadium|in Cincinnati]] on January 9.

===January 1, 2010 (Friday)===
====[[American football]]==== *[[2009–10 NCAA football bowl games|NCAA bowl games]]: **[[Bowl Championship Series|BCS]] games: ***[[2010 Rose Bowl|Rose Bowl Game presented by citi]] in [[Rose Bowl (stadium)|Pasadena, California]]: ****(8) [[2009 Ohio State Buckeyes football team|Ohio State]] 26, (7) [[2009 Oregon Ducks football team|Oregon]] 17 ***[[2010 Sugar Bowl|Allstate Sugar Bowl]] in [[Louisiana Superdome|New Orleans]]: ****(5) [[2009 Florida Gators football team|Florida]] 51, (3) [[2009 Cincinnati Bearcats football team|Cincinnati]] 24 *****2007 [[Heisman Trophy]] winner [[Tim Tebow]] throws for 533 yards and 4 touchdowns in his final college game, as the Bearcats suffer their first loss this season. **Non-BCS games: ***[[2010 Outback Bowl|Outback Bowl]] in [[Raymond James Stadium|Tampa, Florida]]: ****[[2009 Auburn Tigers football team|Auburn]] 38, [[2009 Northwestern Wildcats football team|Northwestern]] 35 (OT) ***[[2010 Gator Bowl|Konica Minolta Gator Bowl]] in [[Jacksonville Municipal Stadium|Jacksonville, Florida]]: ****[[2009 Florida State Seminoles football team|Florida State]] 33, (16) [[2009 West Virginia Mountaineers football team|West Virginia]] 21 ***** Retiring Seminoles head coach [[Bobby Bowden]] exits with a win against the school he coached before coming to Tallahassee in 1976. ***[[2010 Capital One Bowl|Capital One Bowl]] in [[Citrus Bowl|Orlando, Florida]]: ****(13) [[2009 Penn State Nittany Lions football team|Penn State]] 19, (12) [[2009 LSU Tigers football team|LSU]] 17 *****A 21-yard field goal by kicker Collin Wagner with 57 seconds left in the game gives the Nittany Lions their 11th win of the season, after the Tigers rally from 13-point deficit to take a 17–16 lead.
====[[Cross-country skiing]]==== *[[2009–10 Tour de Ski|Tour de Ski]]: **[[2009–10 Tour de Ski#Stage 1|Stage 1]] in [[Oberhof, Germany|Oberhof]], Germany: ***Women's 2.5 km Freestyle: {{gold1}} [[Petra Majdič]] {{cc3|SLO}} 6:35.3 {{Silver2}} [[Natalya Korostelyova]] {{cc3|RUS}} 6:37.4 {{Bronze3}} [[Justyna Kowalczyk]] {{cc3|POL}} 6:41.6 ***Men's 3.75 km Freestyle: {{gold1}} [[Petter Northug]] {{cc3|NOR}} 7:37.4 {{Silver2}} [[Marcus Hellner]] {{cc3|SWE}} 7:38.2 {{Bronze3}} [[Axel Teichmann]] {{cc3|GER}} 7:39.4
====[[Association football|Football (soccer)]]==== *{{Flagicon|JPN}} [[2009 Emperor's Cup#Final|Emperor's Cup Final]] in [[Olympic Stadium (Tokyo)|Tokyo]]: **'''[[Gamba Osaka]]''' 4–1 [[Nagoya Grampus]] ***Gamba Osaka win the Cup for the second successive time and third overall.
====[[Ski jumping]]==== *[[2009–10 Four Hills Tournament|Four Hills Tournament]]: **[[2009–10 Ski Jumping World Cup|World Cup]] in [[Große Olympiaschanze|Garmisch-Partenkirchen]], Germany: ***HS 140: {{gold1}} [[Gregor Schlierenzauer]] {{cc3|AUT}} 277.7 points (136.5m/137.5m) {{Silver2}} [[Wolfgang Loitzl]] {{cc3|AUT}} 272.5 (135.0m/135.0m) {{Bronze3}} [[Simon Ammann]] {{cc3|SUI}} 272.4 (132.0m/143.5 hill record) ****[[2009–10 Four Hills Tournament#Overall standings|Four Hills Tournament standings]] (after 2 of 4 events): (1) [[Andreas Kofler]] {{cc3|AUT}} 537.1 points (2) Loitzl 517.9 (3) [[Janne Ahonen]] {{cc3|FIN}} 512.5 ****[[2009–10 FIS Ski Jumping World Cup#Overall Top 30 (individual)|World Cup standings]] (after 8 of 23 events): (1) Ammann 529 points (2) Schlierenzauer 511 (3) Kofler 426
==References== {{Reflist}}

[[File:Rikishi Monument for Over 50 Consecutive Wins Tomioka Hachiman 2010 September.jpg|thumb|The ''[[#Most consecutive wins|Rikishi Monument for Over 50 Consecutive Wins]]'' at [[Tomioka Hachiman Shrine]]. As of November 2014, the monument carries the names of [[Tanikaze Kajinosuke|Tanikaze]] (63 consecutive wins), [[Umegatani Tōtarō I|Umegatani]] (58), [[Tachiyama Mineemon|Tachiyama]] (56), [[Futabayama Sadaji|Futabayama]] (69), [[Chiyonofuji Mitsugu|Chiyonofuji]] (53) and '''[[Hakuhō Shō|Hakuhō]]''' (63).]] This is a list of records held by wrestlers of professional [[sumo]]. Only performances in official tournaments or ''[[honbasho]]'' are included here. Since 1958 six ''honbasho'' have been held every year, giving wrestlers from the modern era more opportunities to accumulate championships and wins. Before this, tournaments were held less frequently; sometimes only once or twice per year. Names in '''bold''' indicate a still active wrestler. The tables are up to date as of the end of the September 2018 tournament. ==Most top division championships== {{col-begin}} {{col-4}} ===Most career championships=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! !![[Shikona|Name]] !!Total !!Years |- !1 | '''[[Hakuhō Shō|Hakuhō]]''' ||41||2006– |- !2 | [[Taihō Kōki|Taihō]] ||32 ||1960–1971 |- !3 | [[Chiyonofuji]] ||31 ||1981–1990 |- !4 | [[Asashōryū]] ||25 ||2002–2010 |- !5 | [[Kitanoumi]] ||24 ||1974–1984 |- !6 | [[Takanohana Koji|Takanohana II]] ||22 ||1992–2001 |- !7 | [[Wajima Hiroshi|Wajima]] ||14 ||1972–1980 |- !rowspan=2|8 | [[Futabayama]] ||12 ||1936–1943 |- | [[Musashimaru]] ||12 ||1994–2002 |- !10 | [[Akebono Tarō|Akebono]] ||11 ||1992–2000 |} This table does not include best record unofficial championships before the current ''[[yūshō]]'' system was established in 1909.[[Raiden Tameemon|Raiden]] is said to have had the best record in 28 tournaments between 1790 and 1810, [[Tanikaze Kajinosuke|Tanikaze]] 21 between 1772 and 1793, and [[Kashiwado Risuke|Kashiwado]] 16 between 1812 and 1822. [[Tachiyama]] won two unofficial championships and nine official, giving him a total of 11. {{col-4}} ===Most undefeated championships=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! !![[Shikona|Name]] !!Total!!Years |- !1 | '''[[Hakuhō]]''' ||14 ||2007– |- !rowspan=2|2 |[[Futabayama]]||8||1936–1943 |- | [[Taihō Kōki|Taihō]] ||8 ||1963–1969 |- !rowspan=3|4 | [[Tachiyama]] ||7 ||1910–1915 |- | [[Kitanoumi]] ||7 ||1977–1984 |- | [[Chiyonofuji]] ||7 ||1983–1989 |- !7 |[[Tochigiyama]] ||6 ||1917–1925 |- !8 | [[Asashōryū]] ||5 ||2004–2006 |- !rowspan=3|9 |[[Haguroyama Masaji|Haguroyama]] ||4 ||1944–1952 |- |[[Tsunenohana]]|| 4||1921–1928 |- | [[Takanohana Koji|Takanohana II]] ||4 ||1994–1996 |- |} This table lists wrestlers with the most championships achieved without a single loss, which is known as a ''[[zenshō-yūshō]].'' Tournaments have been consistently fifteen days long since May 1949. Before that date there were a number of different lengths, including ten, eleven, twelve, and thirteen days. The records of Tachiyama, Tochigiyama and Tsunenohana also include some draws, holds and rest days. {{col-4}} ===Most consecutive championships=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! !![[Shikona|Name]] !!Total!!Years |- !rowspan=2|1 | [[Asashōryū]] ||7+ ||2004–2005 |- | '''[[Hakuhō]]''' ||7† ||2010–2011 |- !rowspan=3|3 | [[Taihō Kōki|Taihō]] ||6 ||1962–1963 |- | [[Taihō Kōki|Taihō]] ||6 ||1966–1967 |- | '''[[Hakuhō]]''' ||6 ||2014–2015 |- !rowspan=4|5 | [[Futabayama]] ||5‡ ||1936–1938 |- | [[Kitanoumi]] ||5 ||1978 |- | [[Chiyonofuji]] ||5 ||1986–1987 |- |} + Includes a sweep of all six tournaments in 2005. Asashōryū remains the only ''sumotori'' to have won all tournaments in a 6-tournament calendar year (post-1949).
† Four of these titles were ''[[zenshō-yūshō]]'' (undefeated championships) and were part of Hakuhō's second-place streak of 63 consecutive wins.
‡ All of Futabayama's victories in this streak were ''zenshō-yūshō'' (undefeated championships) and were part of Futabayama's record setting 69 consecutive wins. {{col-4}} ===Most championship playoffs=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! !![[Shikona|Name]] !!Total !!Won !!Lost |- !rowspan=2|1 | '''[[Hakuhō]]''' ||10 ||6 ||4 |- | [[Takanohana Koji|Takanohana II]] ||10 ||5 ||5 |- !3 | [[Kitanoumi]] ||8 ||3 ||5 |- !rowspan=2|4 | [[Akebono Tarō|Akebono]] ||7 ||4 ||3 |- | [[Musashimaru]] ||7 ||1 ||6 |- !rowspan=3|6 | [[Chiyonofuji]] ||6 ||6 ||0 |- | [[Asashōryū]] ||6 ||5 ||1 |- | [[Taihō Kōki|Taihō]] ||6 ||4 ||2 |- !9 | [[Hokutoumi]] ||5 ||3 ||2 |- !rowspan=4|10 | [[Wajima Hiroshi|Wajima]] ||4 ||3 ||1 |- | [[Takanonami]] ||4 ||2 ||2 |- | [[Sadanoyama]] ||4 ||1 ||3 |- | [[Wakanohana Masaru|Wakanohana III]] ||4 ||1 ||3 |- |} {{col-end}} ==Most wins== {{Col-begin}} {{Col-break}} ===Most career wins=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! !![[Shikona|Name]] !!Wins !!Years !!Highest rank |- !1 | '''[[Hakuhō]]''' ||1095 ||2001– ||[[Yokozuna]] |- !2 | [[Kaiō Hiroyuki|Kaiō]] ||1047 ||1988–2011 ||[[Ōzeki]] |- !3 | [[Chiyonofuji]] ||1045 ||1970–91 ||Yokozuna |- !4 | [[Oshio Kenji|Ōshio]] ||964 ||1962–88 ||[[Komusubi]] |- !5 |[[Kitanoumi]] ||951 ||1967–84 ||Yokozuna |- !6 |[[Kyokutenhō]] ||927 ||1992–2015 ||[[Sekiwake]] |- !7 | [[Wakanosato]] ||914 ||1992–2015 ||Sekiwake |- !8 | '''[[Aminishiki Ryūji|Aminishiki]]''' ||889 ||1997– ||Sekiwake |- !9 | [[Taihō Kōki|Taihō]] ||872 ||1956–71 ||Yokozuna |- !10 | [[Terao Tsunefumi|Terao]] ||860 ||1979–2002 ||Sekiwake |- |} {{Col-break}} ===Most top division wins=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! !![[Shikona|Name]] !!Wins !!Years !!Highest rank |- !1 | '''[[Hakuhō]]''' ||1001||2004– ||Yokozuna |- !2 | [[Kaiō Hiroyuki|Kaiō]] ||879 ||1993–2011 ||Ōzeki |- !3 | [[Chiyonofuji]] ||807 ||1975–91 ||Yokozuna |- !4 | [[Kitanoumi]] ||804 ||1972–84 ||Yokozuna |- !5 | [[Taihō Kōki|Taihō]] ||746 ||1960–71 ||Yokozuna |- !6 |'''[[Kisenosato]]'''||714|| 2004– ||Yokozuna |- !7 |[[Harumafuji Kōhei|Harumafuji]] ||712 ||2004–17 ||Yokozuna |- !8 | [[Musashimaru]] ||706 ||1991–2003 ||Yokozuna |- !9 | [[Takanohana Koji|Takanohana II]] ||701 ||1990–2003 ||Yokozuna |- !10 |[[Kyokutenhō]] ||697 ||1998–2015 ||Sekiwake |- |} {{Col-break}} ===Most wins in a calendar year (90 bouts)=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! !![[Shikona|Name]] !!Wins !!Year |- !rowspan=2|1 | '''[[Hakuhō]]''' ||86 ||2009 |- | '''Hakuhō''' ||86 ||2010 |- !3 | [[Asashōryū]] ||84 ||2005 |- !rowspan=2|4 | [[Kitanoumi]] ||82 ||1978 |- | '''Hakuhō''' ||82 ||2013 |- !rowspan=2|6 | [[Taihō Kōki|Taihō]] ||81 ||1963 |- | '''Hakuhō''' ||81 ||2014 |- !rowspan=4|8 | Kitanoumi ||80 ||1977 |- | [[Chiyonofuji]] ||80 ||1985 |- | [[Takanohana Koji|Takanohana II]] ||80 ||1994 |- | Takanohana II ||80 ||1995 |- |} {{col-end}} ===Most consecutive wins=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! ![[Shikona|Name]] !Winsthe winning streaks of Tanikaze, Umegatani, and Tachiyama were interrupted by draws and rest days. The others listed were all wins only. !Start !End !Duration !Defeated by |- !1 | [[Futabayama]] ||69 ||7 January 1936 ||3 January 1939|| {{Age in years, months and days|1936|1|7|1939|1|3}} ||[[Akinoumi]] |- !rowspan=2|2 | [[Tanikaze Kajinosuke|Tanikaze]] ||63 ||1 October 1778 ||6 February 1782 || {{Age in years, months and days|1778|10|1|1782|2|6}} || [[Onogawa]] |- | '''[[Hakuhō]]''' ||63 || 14 January 2010 || 2 November 2010 || {{Age in years, months and days|2010|1|14|2010|11|2}} || [[Kisenosato Yutaka|Kisenosato]] |- !4 | [[Umegatani Tōtarō I|Umegatani I]] ||58 || 1 April 1876 ||8 January 1881 || {{Age in years, months and days|1876|4|1|1881|1|8}} || [[Wakashima Kyuzaburo|Wakashima]] |- !5 | [[Tachiyama]] ||56 ||9 January 1912 ||7 May 1916 || {{Age in years, months and days|1912|1|9|1916|5|7}} || [[Tochigiyama]] |- !6 | [[Chiyonofuji]] ||53 ||7 May 1988 ||15 November 1988 || {{Age in years, months and days|1988|5|7|1988|11|15}} || [[Ōnokuni]] |- !7 | [[Taihō Kōki|Taihō]] ||45 || 2 September 1968 || 2 March 1969 || {{Age in years, months and days|1968|9|2|1969|3|2}} || [[Haguroiwa Tomomi|Toda]] |} ===Most consecutive wins from entry into sumo=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! ![[Shikona|Name]] !Wins !Start !End !Duration !Defeated by !Highest rank |- !1 | '''[[Jōkōryū Takayuki|Jōkōryū]]''' ||27||11 July 2011 ||20 January 2012|| {{Age in years, months and days|2011|7|11|2012|1|20}} ||[[Senshō]] ||Komusubi |- !rowspan=2|2 | [[Itai Keisuke|Itai]] ||26|| 12 November 1978 || 16 May 1979 || {{Age in years, months and days|1978|11|12|1979|5|16}} || [[Ōnishiki Ittetsu|Ōnishiki]] ||Komusubi |- | [[Tochiazuma Daisuke|Tochiazuma II]] ||26|| 15 January 1995 || 12 September 1995 || {{Age in years, months and days|1995|1|15|1995|9|12}} || [[Dewaarashi]] ||Ōzeki |- !4 | [[Tokitenkū]] ||22|| 8 September 2002 || 11 March 2003 || {{Age in years, months and days|2002|9|8|2003|3|11}} || [[Furuichi]] ||Komusubi |- !rowspan=5|5 | [[John Tenta|Kototenzan]] ||21|| 12 January 1986 || 20 July 1986 || {{Age in years, months and days|1986|1|12|1986|7|20}} || retired ||[[Makushita]] 43 |- |'''[[Enhō Akira|Enhō]]'''||21||15 May 2017||13 November 2017||{{Age in years, months and days|2017|5|15}}||[[Jōkōryū Takayuki|Jōkōryū]]||[[Juryo]] 14 |} ==Best top division win ratios== {{Col-begin}} {{Col-break}} ===All time=== The list includes ''yokozuna'' and ''ōzeki'' (the highest rank before the ''yokozuna'' rank was introduced), but excludes so-called ''kanban'' or "guest ''ōzeki''" (usually big men drawn from local crowds to promote a tournament who would never appear on the ''[[banzuke]]'' again) and wrestlers for which insufficient data is available. {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! !![[Shikona|Name]] !!Win-Loss !!Years !!rate |- !1 |[[Raiden Tameemon|Raiden]] ||254–10 ||1790–1811 ||96.2% |- !2 |[[Umegatani Tōtarō I|Umegatani I]] ||116–6 ||1874–1885 ||95.1% |- !3 |[[Tanikaze Kajinosuke|Tanikaze]] ||258–14 ||1769–1794 ||94.9% |- !4 |[[Jinmaku Kyūgorō|Jinmaku]] ||87–5 ||1858–1867 ||94.6% |- !5 |[[Onogawa Kisaburō|Onogawa]] ||144–13 ||1781–1797 ||91.7% |- |} {{Col-break}} ===Modern era=== In 1927, Tokyo sumo merged with Osaka sumo and most of the sumo systems were changed, so any pre-1927 records are disregarded. The list excludes active wrestlers.Losses by default are excluded, but wins by default are included; as is standard in sumo records. Among active wrestlers, at the end of the September 2018 tournament, [[Hakuhō]] had 1001 wins against 180 losses, giving a ratio of 84.8%. {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! !![[Shikona|Name]] !!Win-Loss !!Years !!rate |- !1 |[[Taihō Kōki|Taihō]] ||746–144 ||1960–1971 ||83.8% |- !2 |[[Futabayama Sadaji|Futabayama]] ||276–68 ||1932–1945 ||80.2% |- !3 |[[Asashōryū Akinori|Asashōryū]] ||596–153 ||2001–2010 ||79.6% |- !4 |[[Haguroyama Masaji|Haguroyama]] ||321–94 ||1937–1953 ||77.3% |- !5 |[[Kitanoumi Toshimitsu|Kitanoumi]] ||804–247 ||1972–1985 ||76.5% |- |} {{col-end}} ==Most bouts== [[Glossary of sumo terms#fusenpai|Losses by default]] are excluded. {{Col-begin}} {{Col-break}} ===Most career bouts=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! !![[Shikona|Name]] !!Total !!Years !!Highest rank |- !1 |[[Ōshio Kenji|Ōshio]] ||1891 ||1962–1988 ||Komusubi |- !2 |[[Kyokutenhō]] ||1870 ||1992–2015 ||Sekiwake |- !3 |[[Terao Tsunefumi|Terao]] ||1795 ||1979–2002 ||Sekiwake |- !4 |'''[[Aminishiki Ryūji|Aminishiki]]''' ||1758 ||1997– ||Sekiwake |- !5 |[[Kaiō Hiroyuki|Kaiō]] ||1731 ||1988–2011 ||Ōzeki |- !6 |[[Wakanosato]] ||1691 ||1992–2015 ||Sekiwake |- !7 |[[Takamiyama]] ||1654 ||1964–1984 ||Sekiwake |- !8 |[[Aobajō Yukio|Aobajō]] ||1630 ||1964–1986 ||Sekiwake |- !9 |[[Fujizakura Yoshimori|Fujizakura]] ||1613 ||1963–1985 ||Sekiwake |- !10 |[[Akinoshima]] ||1575 ||1982–2003 ||Sekiwake |- |} {{Col-break}} ===Most top division bouts=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! !![[Shikona|Name]] !!Total !!Years !!Highest rank |- !1 |[[Kyokutenhō]] ||1470 ||1998–2015 ||Sekiwake |- !2 |[[Kaio Hiroyuki|Kaiō]] ||1444 ||1993–2011 ||Ōzeki |- !3 |[[Takamiyama]] ||1430 ||1968–1984 ||Sekiwake |- !4 |'''[[Aminishiki Ryūji|Aminishiki]]''' ||1399 ||2000–2018 ||Sekiwake |- !5 |[[Terao Tsunefumi|Terao]] ||1378 ||1985–2001 ||Sekiwake |- !6 |[[Akinoshima]] ||1283 ||1988–2003 ||Sekiwake |- !7 |[[Kotonowaka]] ||1260 ||1990–2005 ||Sekiwake |- !8 |'''[[Takekaze Akira|Takekaze]]''' ||1257||2003–2018 ||Sekiwake |- !9 |[[Kirinji Kazuharu|Kirinji]] ||1221 ||1974–1988 ||Sekiwake |- !10 |'''[[Kotoshōgiku Kazuhiro|Kotoshōgiku]]''' ||1186 ||2005– ||Ōzeki |- |} {{col-end}} ==Most consecutive bouts== {{Col-begin}} {{Col-break}} ===Most consecutive career bouts=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! !![[Shikona|Name]] !!Total !!Years !!Highest rank |- !1 |[[Aobajō Yukio|Aobajō]]* ||1630 ||1964–1986 ||Sekiwake |- !2 |[[Fujizakura]] ||1543 ||1963–1984 ||Sekiwake |- !3 |[[Takatōriki]]* ||1456 ||1983–2002 ||Sekiwake |- !4 |[[Takamiyama]] ||1425 ||1964–1981 ||Sekiwake |- !5 |[[Dairyugawa Kazuo|Dairyūgawa]]* ||1367 ||1961–1979 ||[[Maegashira]] 1 |- !6 |[[Terao]] ||1359 ||1979–1997 ||Sekiwake |- !7 |[[Toyonoumi Shinji|Toyonoumi]]* ||1316||1981–1999 ||Maegashira 1 |- !8 |[[Hidanohana Shigeyoshi|Hidanohana]]* ||1297 ||1969–1989 ||Maegashira 1 |- !9 |[[Ōzutsu Takeshi|Ōzutsu]] ||1267||1978–1992||Sekiwake |- !10 |[[Hachiya Toshiyuki|Hachiya]]*||1263||1968–1987||Maegashira 6 |} * Did not miss any bouts in entire career {{Col-break}} ===Most consecutive top division bouts=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! !![[Shikona|Name]] !!Total !!Years !!Highest rank |- !1 |[[Takamiyama]] ||1231 ||1968–1981 ||Sekiwake |- !2 |[[Ōzutsu Takeshi|Ōzutsu]] ||1170 ||1979–1992 ||Sekiwake |- !3 |[[Kurohimeyama Hideo|Kurohimeyama]] ||1065 ||1969–1981 ||Sekiwake |- !4 |[[Terao]] ||1063 ||1985–1997 ||Sekiwake |- !5 |[[Hasegawa Katsutoshi|Hasegawa]] ||1024 ||1965–1976 ||Sekiwake |- !6 |[[Takatōriki]] ||975 ||1990–2001 ||Sekiwake |- !7 |[[Ohikari Sadayuki|Ohikari]] ||945 ||1950–1963 ||Komusubi |- !rowspan=2|8 |[[Aonosato Sakari|Aonosato]] ||885||1959–1968 ||Sekiwake |- |[[Kaneshiro Kofuku|Kaneshiro]] ||885 ||1974–1984||Sekiwake |- !10 |[[Kitanoumi]]||863||1972–1981||Yokozuna |- |} {{col-end}} ==Most tournaments== The March 2011 tournament was cancelled and is not included in these totals. {{Col-begin}} {{Col-break}} ===Most tournaments ranked in the top division=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! !![[Shikona|Name]] !!Total !!First !!Last !!Highest rank |- !1 | [[Kaio Hiroyuki|Kaiō]] ||107||July 1993 ||July 2011 ||Ōzeki |- !2 | [[Kyokutenhō]] ||99 ||January 1998 ||July 2015 || Sekiwake |- !rowspan=2|3 | [[Takamiyama]] ||97 ||January 1968 ||January 1984 ||Sekiwake |- |'''[[Aminishiki]]''' ||97||July 2000 ||May 2018 || Sekiwake |- !5 | [[Terao Tsunefumi|Terao]] ||93 ||March 1985 ||May 2001 ||Sekiwake |- !6 | [[Akinoshima]] ||91 ||March 1988 ||May 2003 ||Sekiwake |- !7 | [[Kotonowaka]] ||90 ||November 1990 ||November 2005 ||Sekiwake |- !rowspan=2|8 |[[Wakanosato]] ||87 ||May 1998 ||July 2014 ||Sekiwake |- |'''[[Hakuhō Shō|Hakuhō]]''' ||87 ||May 2004 || ||Yokozuna |- !10 |'''[[Takekaze]]''' ||86 ||November 2003 ||May 2018 ||Sekiwake |- |} {{Col-break}} ===Most tournaments ranked at ''yokozuna''=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! !![[Shikona|Name]] !!Total !!First !!Last |- !1 | '''[[Hakuhō]]''' ||68 ||July 2007 ||''September 2018'' |- !2 | [[Kitanoumi]] ||63 ||July 1974 ||January 1985 |- !3 | [[Chiyonofuji]] ||59 ||September 1981 ||May 1991 |- !4 | [[Taiho Koki|Taihō]] ||58 ||November 1961 ||May 1971 |- !5 | [[Takanohana Koji|Takanohana II]] ||49 ||January 1995 ||January 2003 |- !6 | [[Akebono Taro|Akebono]] ||48 ||March 1993 ||January 2001 |- !rowspan=2|7 | [[Kashiwado]] ||47 ||November 1961 ||July 1969 |- | [[Wajima Hiroshi|Wajima]] ||47 ||July 1973 ||March 1981 |- !9 | [[Asashōryū]] ||42 ||March 2003 ||January 2010 |- !10 | [[Chiyonoyama]] ||32 ||September 1951 ||January 1959 |- |} {{col-end}} {{Col-begin}} {{Col-break}} ===Most tournaments ranked at ''ōzeki''=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! !![[Shikona|Name]] !!Total !!First !!Last !!Ended by |- !rowspan=2|1 | [[Chiyotaikai]] ||65 ||March 1999 ||November 2009 ||Demotion |- | [[Kaio Hiroyuki|Kaiō]] ||65||September 2000 ||July 2011 ||Retirement |- !3 | [[Takanohana Kenshi|Takanohana I]] ||50 ||November 1972 ||January 1981 ||Retirement |- !4 | [[Kotoōshū]] ||47 ||January 2006 || November 2013 || Demotion |- !5 | [[Hokuten'yū]] ||44 ||July 1983 ||September 1990 ||Retirement |- !6 | [[Konishiki]] ||39 ||July 1987 ||November 1993 ||Demotion |- !7 | [[Takanonami]] ||37 ||March 1994 ||May 2000 ||Demotion |- !8 | [[Asashio Taro IV|Asashio]] ||36 ||May 1983 ||March 1989 ||Retirement |- !9 | [[Yutakayama Katsuo|Yutakayama]] ||34 ||March 1963 ||September 1968 ||Retirement |- !rowspan=3|10 | [[Kotozakura]] ||32 ||November 1967 ||January 1973 ||Promotion |- | [[Musashimaru]] ||32 ||March 1994 ||May 1999 ||Promotion |- | '''[[Kotoshōgiku]]''' ||32 ||November 2011||January 2017||Demotion |- |} {{Col-break}} ===Most tournaments ranked in junior ''san'yaku'' (''komusubi'' and ''sekiwake'' ranks)=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! !![[Shikona|Name]] !!Total !!First !!Last !!Highest rank |- !1 | [[Kotonishiki]] ||34 ||September 1990 ||September 1999 ||Sekiwake |- !2 | [[Kaio Hiroyuki|Kaiō]] ||32||May 1994 || July 2000 ||Ōzeki |- !3 | [[Musōyama Masashi|Musōyama]] ||31 ||March 1994 ||September 2000 ||Ōzeki |- !rowspan=2|4 | [[Hasegawa Katsutoshi|Hasegawa]] ||30 ||November 1965||September 1974 ||Sekiwake |- | [[Kotomitsuki]] ||30 ||January 2001 ||July 2007 ||Ōzeki |- !rowspan=2|6 | [[Akinoshima]] ||27 ||November 1988 ||September 2000 ||Sekiwake |- | [[Takamiyama]] ||27 ||November 1969 ||September 1982 ||Sekiwake |- !rowspan=2|8 | [[Takatōriki]] ||26 ||May 1991 ||May 2000 ||Sekiwake |- |[[Wakanosato]] ||26 ||November 2000 ||September 2005 ||Sekiwake |- !10 | '''[[Tochiōzan Yūichirō|Tochiōzan]]''' ||25 ||May 2009 ||September 2017 ||Sekiwake |} {{col-end}} ==Progress to top division== The table for the fastest progress shows wrestlers with the fewest tournaments from their professional debut to their [[makuuchi|top division]] debut since the six tournaments a year system was introduced in 1958. It excludes ''[[makushita tsukedashi]]'' and ''[[Glossary_of_sumo_terms#sandanme_tsukedashi|sandanme tsukedashi]]'' entrants who made their debut in the third ''[[makushita]]'' division and the fourth ''[[sandanme]]'' division. {{Col-begin}} {{Col-break}} ===Fastest progress to top division=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! They can only be given to wrestlers ranked at ''[[sekiwake]]'' or below. {{About|the energy drink|the Zayn song|Lucozade (Zayn song)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Infobox Beverage |name = Lucozade |image=[[File:Lucozade logo.png]] |manufacturer= Lucozade Ribena Suntory Limited ([[Suntory]]) |type= [[Soft drink]] |origin=United Kingdom|introduced=1927 |website={{url|http://www.lucozade.com/}} }}
'''Lucozade''' is a [[soft drink]] manufactured by the Japanese company [[Suntory]] and marketed as a range of [[sports drink|sports]] and energy drinks. Created as "Glucozade" in the UK in 1927 by a [[Newcastle-upon-Tyne|Newcastle]] pharmacist, William Walker Hunter<ref name=Northern/> (trading as W. Owen & Son),{{efn|"LUCOZADE-—Word mark. Wares: Non-alcoholic and carbonated beverages of all kinds and essences and syrups for making same. William Walker Hunter, trading as W. Owen & Son, 151, Barras Bridge, Newcastle-uponTyne, England. NS."<ref name=CTD/>}} it was acquired by the British pharmaceutical company [[Beecham Group|Beecham's]] in 1938 and sold as an energy drink for the sick as Lucozade.<ref name=Northern/> The company's advertising slogan was "Lucozade aids recovery".
A [[glucose]]–water solution, the product was sold until 1983 as a [[carbonated]], slightly orange-flavoured drink in a glass bottle wrapped in yellow [[cellophane]].<ref name=Blythe>{{cite book|last1=Blythe|first1=Jim|title=Consumer Behaviour|date=2013|publisher=SAGE|isbn=9781446290323|page=404|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2W5EAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA404|language=en}}</ref> Pharmacists sold it, children were given it when ill, and hospital visitors would regularly arrive with a bottle.<ref name=Delingpole>Delingpole, James (6 May 2017). [https://www.spectator.co.uk/2017/05/jamie-olivers-lucozade-meddling-has-stolen-my-childhood/ "Jamie Oliver’s Lucozade meddling has stolen my childhood"], ''The Spectator''.</ref><ref name=Taylor>{{cite book|last1=Taylor|first1=David|title=Brand Vision: How to Energize Your Team to Drive Business Growth|date=2007|publisher=John Wiley & Sons |isbn=9780470060940|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=Sd-dAFwrxNIC&pg=PA182 182]|language=en}}</ref>{{efn|"Dilly" (''Poppadom Preach'', 2011). "[Dr Johnson suspected that Egg had] picked up a bug of some sort. He said she needed plenty to drink, and suggested Lucozade. Suddenly I wished I was sick as well, because my friendship with Estie had given me a taste for Lucozade: the smell, the bright orange colour, the cellophane wrapping (which could later be used to make X-ray specs), the glugging as it left the bottle like a fizzy golden waterfall, the tiny bubbles jumping out of the glass and popping in the air."<ref>Khan, Almas (2011). ''Poppadom Preach''. Simon and Schuster, 21.</ref>{{pb}} James Willocks and Wallace Barr (2004): "a rush of friends and relations clutching the traditional bunch of flowers and bottle of Lucozade".<ref name=Willocks>{{cite book|last1=Willocks|first1=James|last2=Barr|first2=Wallace|title=Ian Donald: A Memoir|date=2004|publisher=RCOG|isbn=9781904752004|page=55|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6GtmNEpf2fwC&pg=PA55|language=en}}</ref>{{pb}} "Adrian Mole" (''The Lost Diaries of Adrian Mole, 1999–2001'', 2009): "Personally I think it was a great mistake to provide hospital patients with bedside telephones. They give their long-suffering relations no peace with their incessant, peevish demands for Lucozade and boxes of tissues."<ref>Townsend, Sue (2009). ''The Lost Diaries of Adrian Mole, 1999-2001''. Penguin UK, 70.</ref>}} It was rebranded as a "pick me up" in 1978<ref name=Taylor/> and as a sports drink in 1983 to associate it with health rather than sickness. The company switched to a [[plastic bottle]] and introduced a range of flavours.<ref name=Blythe/><ref>{{cite book|last1=Donovan|first1=Tristan|title=Fizz: How Soda Shook Up the World|date=2013|publisher=Chicago Review Press|isbn=9781613747254|page=215|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BTIFAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA215|language=en}}</ref> As of 2016, a 500 ml bottle contained 62 g (15.5 cubes) of [[sugar]], more than [[Coca-Cola]].<ref name=Campbell7May2016/> In 2017, to avoid [[Sugary drink tax|sugar tax]], the drink was reformulated to contain 4.5 g of sugar per 100 ml of liquid<ref>Cave, Andrew (30 October 2017). [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2017/10/30/lucozade-cactus-juice-can-fuel-healthier-living/ "Lucozade Ribena Suntory boss: 'Our drinks can be fuel for healthier living'"], ''The Daily Telegraph''.</ref> and the artificial sweeteners aspartame and acesulfame K.
In 1989 the Beecham Group merged to form SmithKline Beecham, which in 2000 merged to form [[GlaxoSmithKline]]. In September 2013 GlaxoSmithKline sold Lucozade and another soft drink, [[Ribena]], to the Japanese conglomerate Suntory for £1.35 billion.<ref name=Monaghan>Monaghan, Angela. [https://www.theguardian.com/business/2013/apr/24/lucozade-ribena-sale-glaxosmithkline-gsk "Ribena and Lucozade sold to Japanese drinks giant"], ''The Guardian'', 9 September 2013.</ref>
== History == "Glucozade" was invented by William Walker Hunter in 1927 in [[Newcastle-Upon-Tyne|Newcastle]]; Hunter had taken over the business of pharmacist William Owen.<ref name=Northern>{{cite news|title=We did it first|url=http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/business/news/10317055.We_did_it_first/|work=The Northern Echo|date=27 March 2013|language=en}}</ref><ref name=CTD>{{cite web|title=Canadian Trademarks Details 0173483|url=http://www.ic.gc.ca/app/opic-cipo/trdmrks/srch/viewTrademark.html?id=0173483&lang=eng|publisher=Canadian Trademarks Database|accessdate=11 November 2017|language=en}}</ref> Hunter sold the product to [[Beecham Group]] in 1938 and it was eventually renamed to Lucozade.<ref name=Northern/>
In 1953, a factory for the production of Lucozade products was opened in [[Brentford]], which, until 2004, had an iconic sign seen on the side of the [[M4 motorway]] (now in [[Gunnersbury Park]] Museum).<ref name=sign>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/london/3612090.stm|title=Lucozade sign on M4 at GSK's HQ in Brentford removed in 2004|publisher=[[BBC News]] | date=30 August 2004}}</ref>
Lucozade originally was available in only one variety, which was effervescent with a distinctive sweet citric flavour. It was sold in a glass bottle with a yellow cellophane wrap until 1983, when Lucozade was rebranded as an energy drink to shift the brand's associations away from illness. The slogan "Lucozade aids recovery" was replaced by "Lucozade replaces lost energy". The glass bottle was replaced by a plastic ([[polyethylene terephthalate]], PET) one. After the rebranding, between 1984 and 1989 UK sales tripled to almost £75 million.
In 1989 the Beecham Group and SmithKline Beckman merged to form SmithKline Beecham,<ref>{{cite news|title=Profile: SmithKline Beecham|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/606830.stm|work=BBC|date=18 December 2000}}</ref> and in 2000 SmithKline Beecham and GlaxoWellcome merged to form [[GlaxoSmithKline]] (GSK).<ref>{{cite news|title=The Glaxo SmithKline merger|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/607187.stm|work=BBC News|date=17 January 2000}}</ref> In 2013 GSK put Ribena and Lucozade up for sale.<ref name="Neate">{{cite news |author=Rupert Neate |url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2013/apr/24/lucozade-ribena-sale-glaxosmithkline-gsk |title=Lucozade and Ribena up for sale |newspaper=The Guardian |date=24 April 2013}}.</ref> [[Suntory]], a Japanese holding company, bought the brands in September for £1.35 billion.<ref name=Monaghan/> At the time of the sale, the product was manufactured in England at the Royal Forest Factory in [[Coleford, Gloucestershire|Coleford]], [[Gloucestershire]], in the [[Forest of Dean]].<ref name=Monaghan/>
== Products == === Energy Products ===
The following flavours are currently available in the UK: * Lucozade Original * Lucozade Orange * Lucozade Cherry * Lucozade Pink Lemonade * Lucozade Caribbean Crush * Lucozade Pineapple Punch (Launched in 2018) * Lucozade Blackcurrent Bliss (Launched in 2018) * Lucozade The Brazilian * Lucozade Croft Apple (launched in 2018)
The following flavours are currently sold as Zero Energy products: * Lucozade Original Zero * Lucozade Orange Zero * Lucozade Pink Lemonade Zero (New for 2017) * Lucozade Fit Water * Lucozade Sport Raspberry * Lucozade Sport Orange * Lucozade Sport Orange (Low Cal)
The following flavours were previously sold in the UK: * Lucozade Energy Lemon * Lucozade Energy Wild Berry * Lucozade Strawberry * Lucozade Apple * Lucozade Black Cola (Limited edition) * Lucozade Cloudy Lemonade (Limited edition) * Lucozade Melonade (Limited edition)
The following flavours are available in Australia: * Lucozade Original * Lucozade Orange
==Purpose and effectiveness== A stated purpose of sports drinks, which provide many [[calorie]]s of energy from sugars, is to improve performance and endurance. In an analysis by Matthew Thompson and colleagues from the Oxford Centre for [[Evidence Based Medicine]], of 431 marketing claims of performance enhancement, most cited no evidence. 174 sources were cited for Lucozade; of them, Thompson found only three studies of high quality with a low risk of bias. The rigorous studies that did show improved endurance were "of limited relevance to most people because the tests were on elite athletes". Thompson said that for the vast majority of people drinking such products "could completely counteract exercising more, playing football more, going to the gym more".<ref name=telegraph>{{cite news |last=Adams |first=Stephen |title=Sugar-laden sports drinks cancel out exercise gain |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/health/news/9408844/Sugar-laden-sports-drinks-cancel-out-exercise-gain.html |accessdate=16 September 2015 |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=19 July 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Heneghan|first1=C|last2=Perera|first2=R|last3=Nunan|first3=D|last4=Mahtani|first4=K|last5=Gill|first5=P|title=Forty years of sports performance research and little insight gained.|journal=BMJ (Clinical research ed.)|date=18 July 2012|volume=345|pages=e4797|pmid=22810388|doi=10.1136/bmj.e4797}}</ref>
The drinks are marketed as [[soft drink]]s; a soft drinks industry spokesman said in response "By helping people participating in sport to perform better and to recover more quickly, sports drinks can encourage people to exercise more".<ref name=telegraph/>
In May 2016, [[Liverpool City Council]] started a campaign against so-called "[[Junk food|sugary drinks]]". The "name and shame" campaign, entitled “Is your child’s sweet tooth harming their health?”, claimed that Lucozade was the worst offender, containing 62 grams of sugar in a 500 ml bottle, followed by [[Coca-Cola]] with 54 grams. Posters for the campaign "were displayed in doctors' surgeries and hospitals."<ref name=Campbell7May2016>{{cite news|author=Denis Campbell | title=Liverpool in drive to name and shame fizzy drink brands|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2016/may/07/liverpool-fizzy-drink-brands-sugar-obesity|work=The Guardian|date=7 May 2016}}</ref>
In its original high sugar content formulation Lucozade was recommended by UK diabetes charities as an immediate treatment for [[hypoglycemia]] in individuals who take [[insulin]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Hypoglycaemia (hypos)|url=http://www.londondiabetes.nhs.uk/about-diabetes/hypoglycaemia.aspx|accessdate=8 May 2016|publisher=Guy’s and St Thomas’ NHS Foundation Trust and King’s College NHS Foundation Trust |date=19 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.diabetes.co.uk/blog/2017/03/how-will-decreased-sugar-in-lucozade-affect-people-with-diabetes/|title=How will decreased sugar in Lucozade affect people with diabetes?|access-date=10 September 2017}}</ref> Since its change to use of artificial sweeteners guidelines have been changed to state that Lucozade should not be used to treat diabetic hypos.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://diabetestimes.co.uk/new-edition-hospital-hypos-guideline-published/</ref>
==Composition== While the ingredients vary somewhat from one drink to another, the ingredients of the Lucozade Original Energy, were listed as follows in 2013: [[carbonated water]], [[glucose]] syrup (25%), [[citric acid]] (E330), [[lactic acid]] (E270), [[flavouring]] (unspecified), [[preservative]]s ([[potassium sorbate]], [[sodium bisulphite]] (E-222)), [[caffeine]], [[antioxidant]] ([[ascorbic acid]]), colour ([[sunset yellow]] (E110), [[Ponceau 4R]]). Since the reformulation to lower sugar in 2017 Lucozade Original contains the artificial sweeteners aspartame and acesulfame K.
A warning is printed on the packaging that the colouring may have an [[attention deficit hyperactivity disorder|adverse effect on activity and attention]] in children. Nutritional information for 380 ml bottle: [[Food energy|energy]] 1129 k[[joule]]s = 266 [[kCal]]; [[protein]], [[fat]] and [[Dietary fibre|fibre]] nil; [[carbohydrates]] 65.4 g of which [[sugar]]s 33.1 g of which 65.4 g glucose-based; and [[sodium]] trace.<ref name=label>Packaging of Lucozade Energy Original, 2013. Package printed with number 0502229/02</ref> Packaging also warns that spilt Lucozade may stain. A 380 ml bottle of Lucozade contains 46 mg of caffeine,<ref>[https://www.lucozade.com/contact/ Lucozade.com]</ref> about as much as a cup of tea.
Lucozade contains 0.01% [[ethanol]] (alcohol), which kept observant [[Muslim]]s from being allowed to drink it ([[Islamic dietary laws#Intoxicants|Islam bans alcohol]]) until, in 2004, the [[Muslim Council of Britain]] ruled that they saw no harm in consuming Lucozade which contains traces of ethyl alcohol that does not bear its original qualities and does not change the taste, colour or smell. GlaxoSmithKline pointed out that fruit juices and bread could also contain the same or higher trace amounts of alcohol due to natural [[Ethanol fermentation|fermentation]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/3527724.stm|title=Muslims get soft drinks go-ahead|publisher=[[BBC News]]| date=2 August 2004}}</ref>
==Sponsorships== [[File:2014 Women's Rugby World Cup - Samoa 14.jpg|thumb|Lucozade Sport during the [[2014 Women's Rugby World Cup]]]] Lucozade Sport is a major sponsor of events, teams and athletes in the UK and Ireland, including the [[Amateur Rowing Association]] (ARA), [[FA Premier League]], [[FA Cup]], [[Rugby Football Union|England Rugby Football Union]], [[England national football team|England Football Team]], [[Republic of Ireland national football team|the Republic Of Ireland Football Team]], [[London Marathon|the London Marathon]], [[Parkrun]], [[Michael Owen]], [[Steven Gerrard]], [[Damien Duff]], [[Ronan O'Gara]] and [[Ben Wynne]]. From 2012, the [[McLaren]] Formula One team is also sponsored by Lucozade.{{citation needed|date=November 2017}}
== Collaborations == [[File:Lucozade Zero - Rotunda Square, Bullring.jpg|thumb|A Lucozade Zero booth marketing a tie-in with Missguided in 2017 in Birmingham]] In 2017 British fashion supplier [[Missguided]] was included in a campaign by Lucozade Zero. Coded cans were offered at booths in crowded areas that entitled drinkers to discounts on Missguided products.<ref>https://www.promomarketing.info/lucozade-zero-missguided-partner-pack-experiential/</ref>
==Notes== {{notelist}}

'''W''' Walkover |{{bronze3}} |} ==Canoeing== {{main|Canoeing at the 1936 Summer Olympics}} ==Cycling== {{main|Cycling at the 1936 Summer Olympics}} Two male cyclists represented Norway in 1936. ;[[Cycling at the 1936 Summer Olympics – Men's sprint|Sprint]] * [[Haakon Sandtorp]] ;[[Cycling at the 1936 Summer Olympics – Men's 1000m time trial|Time trial]] * [[Harry Haraldsen]] ==Diving== {{main|Diving at the 1936 Summer Olympics}} ==Equestrian== {{main|Equestrian at the 1936 Summer Olympics}} ==Fencing== {{main|Fencing at the 1936 Summer Olympics}} Five fencers, all men, represented Norway in 1936. ;[[Fencing at the 1936 Summer Olympics – Men's foil|Men's foil]] * [[Jens Frølich]] * [[Johan Falkenberg]] * [[Nils Jørgensen]] ;[[Fencing at the 1936 Summer Olympics – Men's team foil|Men's team foil]] * [[Nils Jørgensen]], [[Jens Frølich]], [[Johan Falkenberg]], [[Thorstein Guthe]] ;[[Fencing at the 1936 Summer Olympics – Men's épée|Men's épée]] * [[Egill Knutzen]] * [[Thorstein Guthe]] ==Football== {{main|Football at the 1936 Summer Olympics}} {{Football box collapsible |date = {{Start date|1936|8|3|df=y}} |time = 17:30 |round = Round of 16 |score = 0–4 |report = https://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/mensolympic/berlin1936/matches/round=197043/match=32338/index.html |team1 = {{fb-rt|TUR}} |team2 = {{fb|NOR}} |goals2 = [[Alf Martinsen|Martinsen]] {{goal|30||70}}
[[Arne Brustad|Brustad]] {{goal|53}}
[[Reidar Kvammen|Kvammen]] {{goal|80}} |stadium = [[Mommsenstadion]] |location = [[Berlin]] |attendance = 8,000 |referee = Giuseppe Scarpi ([[Italian Football Federation|Italy]]) |result = W }} {{Football box collapsible |date = {{Start date|1936|8|7|df=y}} |time = 17:30 |round = Quarterfinals |score = 0–2 |report = https://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/mensolympic/berlin1936/matches/round=197044/match=32346/index.html |team1 = {{fb-rt|GER|1935}} |team2 = {{fb|NOR}} |goals2 = [[Magnar Isaksen|Isaksen]] {{goal|7||83}} |stadium = [[Poststadion]] |location = [[Berlin]] |attendance = 55,000 |referee = [[Arthur W. Barton]] ([[The Football Association|England]]) |result = W }} {{Football box collapsible |date = {{Start date|1936|8|10|df=y}} |time = 17:00 |round = Semifinals |score = 2–1 |aet = yes |report = https://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/mensolympic/berlin1936/matches/round=197046/match=32349/index.html |team1 = {{fb-rt|ITA|1861}} |goals1 = [[Alfonso Negro|Negro]] {{goal|15}}
[[Annibale Frossi|Frossi]] {{goal|96}} |team2 = {{fb|NOR}} |goals2 = [[Arne Brustad|Brustad]] {{goal|58}} |stadium = [[Olympiastadion (Berlin)|Olympiastadion]] |location = [[Berlin]] |attendance = 95,000 |referee = Pál von Hertzka ([[Hungarian Football Federation|Hungary]]) |result = L }} {{Football box collapsible |date = {{Start date|1936|8|13|df=y}} |time = 16:00 |round = Bronze Medal Match |score = 3–2 |report = https://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/mensolympic/berlin1936/matches/round=197047/match=32351/index.html |team1 = {{fb-rt|NOR}} |goals1 = [[Arne Brustad|Brustad]] {{goal|15||21||84}} |team2 = {{fb|POL|1928}} |goals2 = [[Gerard Wodarz|Wodarz]] {{goal|5}}
[[Teodor Peterek|Peterek]] {{goal|24|pen.}} |stadium = [[Olympiastadion (Berlin)|Olympiastadion]] |location = [[Berlin]] |attendance = 82,000 |referee = Alfred Birlem ([[German Football Association|Germany]]) |bg = CD7F32 }} ==Rowing== {{main article|Rowing at the 1936 Summer Olympics}} Norway had one rower participate in one out of seven [[rowing (sport)|rowing]] events in 1936.{{cite Sports-Reference |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/countries/NOR/summer/1936/ROW/ |title=Norway Rowing at the 1936 Berlin Summer Games |accessdate= 9 May 2018}} ; [[Rowing at the 1936 Summer Olympics – Men's single sculls|Men's single sculls]] * [[Carl Christiansen (rower)|Carl Christiansen]] ==Sailing== {{main|Sailing at the 1936 Summer Olympics}} ==Shooting== {{main|Shooting at the 1936 Summer Olympics}} Four shooters represented Norway in 1936. [[Willy Røgeberg]] won the gold medal in the 50 m rifle event. ;[[Shooting at the 1936 Summer Olympics – Men's 25 metre rapid fire pistol|25 m rapid fire pistol]] * [[Hans Aasnæs]] ;[[Shooting at the 1936 Summer Olympics – Men's 50 metre pistol|50 m pistol]] * [[Mauritz Amundsen]] ;[[Shooting at the 1936 Summer Olympics – Men's 50 metre rifle, prone|50 m rifle, prone]] * [[Willy Røgeberg]] * [[Mauritz Amundsen]] * [[Hakon Aasnæs]] ==Wrestling== {{main|Wrestling at the 1936 Summer Olympics}} *[[Olaf Knudsen]] *[[Arild Dahl]] *[[Ivar Stokke]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.la84foundation.org/5va/reports_frmst.htm Official Olympic Reports] *[http://www.olympic.org/uk/athletes/results/search_r_uk.asp International Olympic Committee results database] {{country at games navbox|Norway|Olympics}} {{Nations at the 1936 Summer Olympics}} [[Category:Nations at the 1936 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Norway at the Summer Olympics by year|1936]] [[Category:1936 in Norwegian sport]] {{Norway-hist-stub}} {{1936-Olympic-stub}}

revision.text:
'''PlaySight Interactive''' is a sports video and analytics technology company, offering its SmartCourt platform across several sports, including tennis and basketball.<ref name=WhatIsPlaysight>{{cite web|title=What is PlaySight|url=https://www.playsight.com/Home/WhatIsPlaySight|website=PlaySight|accessdate=22 May 2017}}</ref> There are over 900 SmartCourts installed around the world, including with the NBA's [[Golden State Warriors]], [[Toronto Raptors]] and [[Phoenix Suns]] and close to 50 [[NCAA]] sports programs, including [[Harvard University]], the [[University of Southern California]], and [[Princeton University]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Tennis Technology: Smarten up!|url=http://www.tennisindustrymag.com/articles/2016/11/14_tennis_technology_smarten_u.html|website=Tennis Industry Magazine|accessdate=22 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Leung|first1=Diamond|title=PlaySight’s SmartCourt expansion into pro basketball begins with Golden State|url=https://www.si.com/tech-media/2016/12/12/playsight-smartcourt-golden-state-warriors|website=Sports Illustrated}}</ref><ref name=SecretWeapon>{{cite web|last1=Rossingh|first1=Danielle|title=US Open: Is a smart court the secret weapon to beat Serena Williams?|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2016/09/07/sport/us-open-simona-halep-serena-willims-secret-weapon|website=CNN|accessdate=22 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=PlaySight Live Streaming the 2017 NCAA Championships from the University of Georgia|url=https://www.collegetennistoday.com/item/1524-playsight-live-streaming-the-2017-ncaa-championships-from-the-university-of-georgia.html|website=College Tennis Today|accessdate=22 May 2017}}</ref> The [[United States Tennis Association]] installed PlaySight's SmartCourt technology on 32 courts at its new national campus in Lake Nona, Florida.<ref name=Eyes>{{cite web|last=Rothenberg|first=Ben|title=An Electronic Set of Eyes to Feed Data to Tennis Players and Coaches|url= https://www.nytimes.com/2016/08/28/sports/tennis/an-electronic-set-of-eyes-to-feed-data-to-tennis-players-and-coaches.html|website=NYtimes|date=2016-08-27 |accessdate=2018-02-14}}</ref> PlaySight was named one of Fast Company's Most Innovative Companies for 2017.<ref>{{cite web|title=Most Innovative Companies|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/company/playsight|website=Fast Company|accessdate=22 May 2017}}</ref><ref>https://www.sporttechie.com/playsight-partners-with-recently-retired-ana-ivanovic-as-tech-platform-continues-growth/</ref>
== Company history == In 2010, PlaySight was founded in [[Kfar Saba]], Israel, using technology with roots in the Israeli military.<ref name=Boom>{{cite web|last1=Daniel|first1=Kaplan|title=Smart court maker PlaySight helps push boom in tennis tech|url=http://www.sportsbusinessdaily.com/Journal/Issues/2015/11/30/Research-and-Ratings/Company-Watch.aspx |publisher=SportsBusiness Journal|accessdate=22 May 2017}}</ref> After years developing weaponry and war simulators for the Israeli army and other defense clients, the three partners looked to apply their skills and knowledge to a new challenge. After one of the partners, Evgeni Khazanov, observed his daughter’s tennis practice, he wondered why a sport with so much money did not have any advanced technology to help players improve their game. It was from that idea that PlaySight was born.
PlaySight has continued to grow through partnerships and investment from players in the tennis industry including [[Billie Jean King]], [[Ana Ivanovic]], [[Chris Evert]], [[Pete Sampras]], [[Novak Djokovic]], [[Tommy Haas]], [[Paul Annacone]], and [[Darren Cahill]].<ref>{{cite web|title=WTA Grand Slam Singles Champion and Former World #1 Ana Ivanovic Joins the PlaySight Team|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/wta-grand-slam-singles-champion-143000759.html|website=Yahoo Finance|publisher=PRNewswire}}</ref> Other notable investors include Bill Ackman, Mark Ein, Dr. James Loehr, Gordon Uehling III, and George Mackin. Since the technology was commercialized in 2013,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Schmidt|first1=Colleen|title=High-tech training tool sets new standard on courts at Alberta Tennis Centre|url=http://calgary.ctvnews.ca/high-tech-training-tool-sets-new-standard-on-courts-at-alberta-tennis-centre-1.3356496|website=CTV News Calgary|accessdate=22 May 2017}}</ref> the technology has been adapted for numerous other sports including soccer, martial arts, volleyball, squash, handball, gymnastics, dancing, hockey and wrestling. So far, PlaySight has raised over $20 million and now has offices in Kfar Saba, New Jersey and Los Angeles.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Rubin|first1=Eliran|title=The Israeli Startups Leading the Digital Sports Revolution|url=http://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/business/1.776328|website=Haaretz}}</ref>
In June 2017, [[Verizon]] Ventures and golfer [[Greg Norman]] announced an $11 million investment in PlaySight to further SmartCourt expansion in tennis, basketball and other sports and to also introduce the technology to golf.<ref>https://www.forbes.com/sites/daniellerossingh/2017/06/02/greg-norman-verizon-ventures-invest-11m-in-developing-smart-golf-course/#7175a5196a00</ref>
PlaySight installed its first SmartSchools in 2017 – fully wired high school campuses (including [[Trinity-Pawling School]], [[Oaks Christian School]] and [[Sierra Canyon School]] with PlaySight across several sports – basketball, ice hockey, soccer and more.<ref name=School>{{cite web|url= https://frntofficesport.com/playsight-goes-back-to-school/ |title=PlaySight Goes Back to School |work=Front Office Sports |date=2017-08-23 |accessdate=2018-02-14}}</ref>
== Method of operation == A PlaySight "SmartCourt" is a system of fully automated HD cameras that record, stream and analyze all on-court action.<ref name=SecretWeapon /><ref>https://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/newslocal/southern-courier/sport/feel-like-a-star-with-hitech-tennis-court/news-story/98c3281c7cf9a907473c785103ac3dcd</ref>For tennis, the technology uses image processing and analytical algorithms to track strokes, ball trajectory, player movement and shot speed and spin.<ref name=Boom /> PlaySight's SmartCourt system provides players and coaches instant multi-angle video and detailed statistics through the court side kiosk and on tablets and mobile devices.<ref name=Eyes /> Their cloud-based platform allows teams to live stream matches and stores all video from SmartCourt sessions for coaches and players to review later from any web enabled device.<ref name=WhatIsPlaysight /><ref>http://www.verizonventures.com/blog/2017/06/entrepreneur-spotlight-chen-shachar,-founder-ceo-of-playsight/</ref> In 2017, PlaySight unveiled its SmartField technology for soccer<ref name=Booton>{{cite web |url= https://www.sporttechie.com/playsight-expands-4k-video-instant-replays-soccer/ |title=PlaySight Expands 4K Training Video, Instant Replays To Soccer |last=Booton |first=Jen |date=2017-10-25 |work=SportTechie |accessdate=2018-02-14}}</ref> and also released its SmartTracker technology - an autonomous 4K camera that follows all on-court action automatically.<ref name=School />
== PlayFair challenge system for tennis == Cheating has become a prominent issue in tennis particularly on junior circuits where players call their own lines.<ref name=Cheat>{{cite web|last1=Danielle|first1=Rossingh|title=Is This The End For The Tennis Club Cheat?|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/daniellerossingh/2016/10/31/is-this-the-end-for-the-tennis-club-cheat/#6f93e77a3803|website=Forbes|accessdate=22 May 2017}}</ref><ref name=SecretWeapon /> PlaySight developed the idea of PlayFair Tournaments that use the line-calling feature of PlaySight's SmartCourt technology to tackle the cheating problem in tennis.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Pantic|first1=Nina|title=PLAYFAIR TOURNAMENTS ARE DETERRING CHEATING, EMPHASIZING SPORTSMANSHIP|url=http://www.tennis.com/pro-game/2016/12/playfair-tournaments-are-deterring-cheating-emphasizing-sportsmanship/62436/|website=Tennis Magazine|accessdate=22 May 2017}}</ref> These tournaments allow players to challenge close line calls and use the PlaySight court side kiosk to access video replay to confirm or overrule the call.<ref name=Cheat /> PlayFair Tournaments have been organized at both the junior club and collegiate levels.'
In late 2017, PlaySight and the ITA announced an expansion of the PlayFair initiative, bringing the technology to close to 30 NCAA dual matches for the 2018 season.<ref>http://www.itatennis.com/AboutITA/News/Intercollegiate_Tennis_Association_And_PlaySight_Expand_PlayFair_Challenge_System_Pilot_Tests.htm</ref>
== Expansion into new sports == PlaySight expanded into basketball, volleyball, soccer, and several other sports in 2017.<ref name=Booton /><ref>https://www.sporttechie.com/playsight-brings-its-smartcourts-to-the-high-school-level/</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Sports technology]] [[Category:Technology companies of Israel]]

{{Infobox venue | name = RE/MAX Field | nickname = | fullname = | former names = Telus Field (1995-2015)
Edmonton Ballpark (2016) | logo_image = File:REMAX_Field.png | logo_caption = Logo since 2017 | image = Telus Field evening 2012.jpg | caption = | pushpin_map = Canada Edmonton | pushpin_map_caption= Location in Edmonton | coordinates = {{coord|53|31|54|N|113|29|48|W|type:landmark_region:CA-AB|display=inline,title}} | address = 10233 96 Avenue,
[[Edmonton]], [[Alberta]] | type = baseball stadium | broke_ground = | built = | opened = {{Start date|1995|May|2}} | renovated = | closed = | demolished = | owner = City of Edmonton | operator = | surface = [[FieldTurf]] (infield) (2005–present)
[[Astroturf]] (infield) (1995–2004)
Grass (outfield) | cost = | architect = | capacity = 9,200{{cite web|title=Edmonton Prospects Location|url=http://www.prospectsbaseballclub.com/location/location|website=Prospects Baseball Club|publisher=Prospects Baseball Club|accessdate=12 May 2017}}{{cite web|title=Stadiums in Canada, Alberta|url=http://www.worldstadiums.com/north_america/countries/canada/alberta.shtml|website=World Stadiums|accessdate=June 1, 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150121093915/http://www.worldstadiums.com/north_america/countries/canada/alberta.shtml|archivedate=January 21, 2015|df=mdy-all}} | suites = 30{{cite web|title=Edmonton Ballpark (formerly known as Telus Field)|url=http://www.ticketmaster.ca/Telus-Field-tickets-Edmonton/venue/139314|publisher=Ticketmaster|accessdate=June 1, 2016}} | record_attendance = | dimensions = Left: {{convert|340|ft|abbr=on}}
Centre: {{convert|420|ft|abbr=on}}
Right: {{convert|320|ft|abbr=on}} | tenants = [[Edmonton Trappers]] ([[Pacific Coast League|PCL]]) (1995–2004)
[[Edmonton Capitals|Edmonton Cracker-Cats/Capitals]] ([[North American League (baseball)|NAL]]) (2005–2011)
[[Edmonton Prospects]] ([[Western Major Baseball League|WMBL]]) (2005, 2012–present)
[[Fort McMurray Giants]] ([[Western Major Baseball League|WMBL]]) (2016) | website = {{URL|http://www.remaxfield.com/}} | publictransit = }} '''RE/MAX Field''' (formerly '''Edmonton Ballpark''', and '''Telus Field''' stylized as TELUS) is a [[baseball stadium]] in [[Edmonton]], [[Alberta]], Canada. It has served as home to several [[minor league baseball]] clubs, currently the [[Edmonton Prospects]] of the [[Western Major Baseball League]]; its last affiliated tenant was the [[Edmonton Trappers]], a AAA [[Pacific Coast League]] club, and its most recent tenant was the [[Edmonton Capitals]], an independent team that has been inactive since 2011. In 2016 the Prospects were granted naming rights to the facility as the old name had expired. The facility is located in the [[North Saskatchewan River valley parks system|North Saskatchewan River Valley]], in the neighbourhood of [[Rossdale, Edmonton|Rossdale]]. ==History== [[File:Telus Field.jpg|thumb|250px|Telus Field in 2010]] Opened in 1995, Telus Field replaced the 60-year-old [[John Ducey Park]] (formerly ''Renfrew Park'') on the same site. The stadium's [[naming rights]] were purchased by the [[Telus]] [[telecommunications]] company in September 1995 for a 14-year deal.{{cite news | last = Spector | first = Mark | title = Ball park has name until end of 2009 | newspaper = Edmonton Journal | pages = C.3 | publisher = Edmonton Journal | date = 1995-09-08 | accessdate = 2008-03-07 }} It has {{convert|12|ft|m}} walls all the way around except in centre field, where the batter's eye is a {{convert|34|ft|m|adj=on}} [[green monster]] which is the third highest wall in professional baseball.{{cite web|last1=Kinmartin|first1=Patrick|title=Outlaws Notebook: The force could be with Luyben|url=http://www.chicoer.com/20080814/outlaws-notebook-the-force-could-be-with-luyben|publisher=ChicoER News|accessdate=June 1, 2016|date=August 14, 2008}} Three players, [[Matthew LeCroy]], [[Michael Cuddyer]], and [[Todd Sears]] have hit home runs over it.{{cite web|last1=Zerr|first1=Scott|title=Moon shot by Cuddyer leads home team past Grizzlies|url=http://www.angelfire.com/va3/cuddyer/article17.html|website=Angelfire|accessdate=June 1, 2016|date=June 12, 2002}} Telus Field held the IBAF World Cup Women's baseball in the summer of 2004 and from July 25 to August 3, 2008, the park held the [[IBAF AAA World Junior Championships]] for the 7th time since it started in 1981. Despite Telus's naming rights expiring in 2009{{cite web|last1=Tkach|first1=Marek|title=Edmonton’s nameless river valley gem|url=http://naitnewswatch.ca/articles/edmontons-nameless-river-valley-gem/|publisher=NAIT News Watch|accessdate=June 1, 2016|date=April 21, 2016}} the stadium continued to use the name Telus Field until opening the 2016 season as Edmonton Ballpark,{{cite web|last1=Lamb|first1=Adrienne|title=Telus Field gets a new name and lease on life|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/edmonton-prospects-telus-field-new-name-1.3560235|publisher=CBC News|accessdate=June 1, 2016|date=April 30, 2016}} or simply Ballpark.{{cite web|author=Julie|title=Open House Saturday, May 21|url=http://www.prospectsbaseballclub.com/edmonton-prospects-news/news/358-open-house-saturday-may-21|publisher=Edmonton Prospects|accessdate=June 1, 2016}} Being displaced by the [[2016 Fort McMurray wildfire]], the [[Fort McMurray Giants]] played their inaugural season at the then Edmonton Ballpark.{{cite web|last1=Heidenreich|first1=Phil|title=Fort McMurray Giants to play baseball in Edmonton this season|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/2705528/fort-mcmurray-giants-to-play-baseball-in-edmonton-this-season/|publisher=[[CITV-DT|Global Edmonton]]|accessdate=June 1, 2016|date=May 16, 2016}} In May 2017 the stadium was renamed RE/MAX Field by the Edmonton Prospects; gaining naming rights and naming the park after the team's sponsor, [[RE/MAX]], for three years.{{cite news|last1=Mertz|first1=Emily|title=Edmonton’s Telus Field is renamed Re/Max Field|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/3418814/edmontons-telus-field-is-renamed-remax-field/|accessdate=May 2, 2017|agency=Global Edmonton|publisher=Corus Entertainment Inc.|date=May 1, 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Graney|first1=Juris|title=Edmonton's home of baseball gets a new name|url=http://www.edmontonsun.com/2017/05/01/edmontons-home-of-baseball-gets-a-new-name|accessdate=May 2, 2017|agency=Edmonton Sun|publisher=Postmedia|date=May 1, 2017}} ==Features== RE/MAX Field uses natural grass in the outfield and [[FieldTurf]] in the infield; originally [[AstroTurf]] was used but it was replaced in 2005 with the more modern type of turf, FieldTurf. Artificial turf was chosen for lower maintenance costs, because it allows for a better drainage system so the infield can return to a playable state quicker than a grass infield would, and to minimize damage to the infield when concerts are held at the stadium. The park has ground-level luxury suites with box and general seating built on top. The Home Plate VIP Lounge on the main concourse is located directly behind the plate, incorporating a bar and a restaurant with a view of the field from seats inside and outside. The lounge includes trophies and pictures of early Edmonton baseball teams.{{Cite web|url=http://nlfan.com/edmonton/homePlateClub.shtml |title=Home Plate Club/Lounge |publisher=nlfan.com |access-date=June 1, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071014204036/http://nlfan.com/edmonton/homePlateClub.shtml |archive-date=October 14, 2007 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy }} The capacity of the stadium is 9,200. The dimensions are {{convert|340|ft|m}} to left field, {{convert|378|ft|m}} to left centre, {{convert|420|ft|m}} to centre field, {{convert|395|ft|m}} to right centre and {{convert|320|ft|m}} to right field.{{citation needed|date=June 2016}} The stadium concourse features pictures of historic moments in Trapper history, including [[Ron Kittle]]'s 50-home-run season. There are also pictures from every Trapper championship and trophies.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}} ==Concerts== Concerts have been held at the stadium on occasion: * 1995 concerts included Tom Cochrane; Jeff Healey; The Beach Boys; The Village People and others. * July 15, 2000: '''Briefcase Blues''' in concert following an Edmonton Trappers game - after which the band members signed baseballs for fans. * August 22, 2001: [[Blink-182]] with [[Jimmy Eat World]], [[New Found Glory]], Sum 41 * June 13, 2002: [[Newsboys]]{{cite web|title=AKE launches Canadian tour with the Newsboys|url=http://www.christianactivities.com/jake-launches-canadian-tour-newsboys|publisher=Christian Activities|accessdate=June 1, 2016|date=June 7, 2002}} * November 20, 2005: 2005 Tuyul Rugby Sevens * August 25, 2009: [[Big & Rich]] with [[Cowboy Troy]], [[Dean Brody]], Mike Plume Band * September 4, 2009: [[Bryan Adams]] * August 28, 2010: Rock the River West Tour (featuring [[Skillet (band)|Skillet]], [[Flyleaf (band)|Flyleaf]], [[Hawk Nelson]], [[Starfield (band)|Starfield]], [[Downhere]], and [[Tedashii]]) ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category}} * {{URL|http://www.prospectsbaseballclub.com/|Edmonton Prospects}} {{Edmonton landmarks}} {{use mdy dates|date=June 2016}} [[Category:1995 establishments in Alberta]] [[Category:Baseball in Edmonton]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Alberta]] [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Rugby union stadiums in Canada]] [[Category:Sports venues in Edmonton]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Edmonton]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1995]] [[Category:Music venues in Edmonton]]

{{lead missing|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Ralph F. DellaCamera Stadium | image =<!-- [[File://localhost/Users/schnab2/Desktop/University-of-New-Haven-685x277.jpg|thumbnail|Ralph F. DellaCamera Stadium]] --> | caption = Ralph F. DellaCamera Stadium is located in the lower-right portion of this photo, on the [[University of New Haven]]'s North Campus. | nickname = | location = [[West Haven, Connecticut|West Haven]], [[Connecticut]] | coordinates = {{Coord|41.29583|-72.9673|type:landmark_region:US-IL|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | opened = September 19, 2009 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[University of New Haven]] | operator = [[University of New Haven]] | surface = Blue & Gold [[Artificial turf|Sprinturf]] | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = | tenants = | seating_capacity = 5,000<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.northeast10.org/sports/fball/mediacenter/UNH/index|publisher=[[Northeast 10 Conference]]|title=Football Media Center (University of New Haven)|accessdate=January 13, 2013}}</ref> }}
==About== '''Ralph F. DellaCamera Stadium''' is a sport stadium in [[West Haven, Connecticut|West Haven]], [[Connecticut]]. The facility is primarily used by the [[University of New Haven]] athletic teams, as well as the University of New Haven Chargers Marching Band.<ref name="Tom McMahon">{{cite web|url=http://www.tommcmahon.net/2008/11/another-blue-football-field-ralph-f-dellacamera-stadium-at-the-university-of-new-haven.html|publisher=Tom McMahon.net|title=Another Blue Football Field: Ralph F. DellaCamera Stadium at the University of New Haven|date=November 19, 2008|accessdate=January 12, 2013}}</ref>
The field turf is not the normal selection of green, but is instead blue. The selection of blue—a non-traditional field color—was made to generate excitement and publicity while the school was re-establishing its college football program.<ref name="Tom McMahon" /> As of the 2012 season, New Haven is only one of five college programs to have the field color other than the traditional green<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lindenwood.edu/news/2012/885-BV.html|publisher=[[Lindenwood University]]|accessdate=September 7, 2012|title=Lindenwood Stadium Nearing Final Stages of Renovations|date=July 16, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120911043931/http://www.lindenwood.edu/news/2012/885-BV.html|archivedate=September 11, 2012|df=}}</ref>
The first [[college football]] game played at the stadium was a 25–18 loss to the [[Bentley University|Bentley University Falcons]] on September 26, 2009.
The stadium is also used for local high school sporting events and other community events.
==Non-Athletic Uses== The [[University of New Haven]] used DellaCamera Stadium for its Spring Commencement until May 2011, where the University moved the ceremony to the [[Oakdale Theatre]].
==See also== * [[List of college football stadiums with non-traditional field colors]]
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Infobox company |name = Saeta International Sports Wear Ltda |logo = Saeta Logo.svg |logo_size = 200px |type = [[Private company|Private]] |foundation = 1982 |location = [[Bogotá]], [[Colombia]] |key_people = |industry = [[Sportswear (activewear)|Sportswear]] |products = [[Footwear]]
[[Sportswear (activewear)|Sportswear]] |revenue = |homepage = [http://www.saetasport.com/ www.saetasport.com] }} '''Saeta International Sport Wear''' is a Colombian company that operates its business in the textile sector, in the manufacture, import{{cite web|url = http://www.comxport.com/paises/michella_fischai_heist-colombia-26746.php|title = Importaciones Saeta|author = www.comxport.com}} and export{{cite web|url = http://www.colombiaexport.com/saete.htm|title = Exportaciones Saeta|author = www.colombiaexport.com}} of sportswear and accessories. ==History== In 1982, a Colombian businessman decides to acquire a loan to buy a machine to manufacture sweatshirts, and with an expert in making clothes and industrial designer started the company. In 1988, Saeta tailored uniforms to 13 professional football teams in Colombia, which had the sponsorship of a prestigious beverage company, owned by one of the most important economic groups in the country. Saeta thus becomes the main supplier of sportswear at the national level. In 1991, the distribution company of sportswear, Rydtex of Sweden, came to Colombia in search of new suppliers and learn about the quality of Saeta, carried out the orders. These orders were the first export of the company. 1998, becoming the sponsor of one of the most famous professional teams in the country, the brand reached a high level of recognition. 2001, co-sponsored negotiations with other major professional team, which is followed by active promotion of the company's flagship product.{{cite web|url = http://redalyc.uaemex.mx/pdf/631/63190103.pdf|title = Fórmula para salir de la crisis|author = uaemex.mx}} ==Sponsorship== {{Unreferenced section|date=June 2015}} SAETA has sponsored several teams of Colombian professional soccer from [[Categoría Primera A]] and [[Categoría Primera B]]. [[File:Guyana Away shirt 2012.jpg|thumb|right|Official [[Guyana national football team|Guyana]] home shirt from 2012, made by Saeta.]] ===National teams=== *{{fb|Haiti}} (2013–) ===Club teams=== *{{flagicon|Colombia}} [[Once Caldas|Once Caldas]] (2018-) *{{flagicon|Colombia}} [[Independiente Santa Fe|Santa Fe]] (1983–1995) *{{flagicon|Colombia}} [[América de Cali]] (1991–1992, 2010) *{{flagicon|Colombia}} [[Cúcuta Deportivo]] (1999–2004)(2015– ) *{{flagicon|Colombia}} [[Millonarios F.C.|Millonarios]] (2000–2002, 2005–2008) *{{flagicon|Colombia}} [[Real Cartagena]] (2005–2007, 2009–2010) *{{flagicon|Colombia}} [[Deportivo Pasto]] (2008) == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.saetasport.com Web site] * [http://www.saetausa.com U.S.A. Web Site] [[Category:Sportswear brands]] [[Category:Companies of Colombia]] [[Category:Companies based in Bogotá]] [[Category:Companies established in 1982]] [[Category:Colombian brands]] [[Category:Clothing brands of Colombia]] [[Category:Sporting goods manufacturers of Colombia]]
